fr:title.text: Fibre products of schemes are topological

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Fibre products of schemes are topological

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let X,Y,S be schemes with morphisms f : X \to S and g : Y \to S. Then the pullback X \times _S Y exists in the category of schemes, and its underlying topological space is the pullback in the category of topological spaces.

The existence of the fibre products follows from the usual gluing argument for schemes, and reduces to the fibre products of affine schemes. For affine schemes, the fibre products are computed by the spectrum of pushouts, because we have seen from Theorem \operatorname {Spec} is a right adjoint.

fr:title.text: Fibre products of schemes are topological

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Fibre products of schemes are topological

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let X,Y,S be schemes with morphisms f : X \to S and g : Y \to S. Then the pullback X \times _S Y exists in the category of schemes, and its underlying topological space is the pullback in the category of topological spaces.

The existence of the fibre products follows from the usual gluing argument for schemes, and reduces to the fibre products of affine schemes. For affine schemes, the fibre products are computed by the spectrum of pushouts, because we have seen from Theorem \operatorname {Spec} is a right adjoint.

fr:title.text: Pushouts of algebras are tensor products

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Pushouts of algebras are tensor products

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
Given u : A \to C and v : B \to C with uf = vg, we construct a map [u,v] : A \otimes _D B \to C by sending a generator a \otimes b to ua \wedge vb. We need to show this respects the congruence of the tensor product:
[u,v](a \otimes 0) = ua \wedge v0 = 0 = [u,v], and similarly for 0 \otimes b.
[u,v](a \vee a' \otimes b) = u(a \vee a') \wedge vb = (ua \wedge vb) \vee (ua' \wedge vb) = [u,v](a \otimes b \vee a' \otimes b), and similarly for a \otimes b\vee b'.
[u,v][aa' \otimes bb'] = u(aa') \wedge v(bb') = ua \wedge ua' \wedge vb \wedge vb' = [u,v](a\otimes b \wedge a' \otimes b').
[u,v](ad \otimes b) = ua \wedge ufd \wedge vb = ua \wedge vgd \wedge vb = [u,v](a \otimes db). Hence, the map [u,v] is well-defined, and in fact uniquely determined by the two inclusions A \to A \otimes _DB and B \to A \otimes _DB.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A locally distributed space (X,\mathcal {O}_{X}) is a scheme, if for any x\in X there is an open neighbourhood U of x, such that (U,\mathcal {O}_{X}|_U) is an affine scheme. The full subcategory of schemes will be denoted as \mathbf {Sch}_{\mathbb {D}}.

On the other hand, we need to show that for any morphism between locally distributed spaces (f,f^{\sharp }) : (X,\mathcal {O}_{X}) \to (\operatorname {Spec} D,\mathcal {O}_{D}), it is determined by f_{\sharp } : D \to \Gamma \mathcal {O}_{X}. Fistly, since D\twoheadrightarrow D/p is a localisation, all the morphisms f_{\sharp } : D/p \to _{\sharp } X(f^{-1} p) are already determined by f_{\sharp } : D \to \Gamma \mathcal {O}_{X}. Hence, it suffices to show that f is also determined by f_{\sharp } : D \to \Gamma \mathcal {O}_{X}. The key of course is the requirement that f^{\sharp } is t-conservative. By the Kripke-Joyal semantics, this means that for any x\in X, the induced map on stalk D/fx \to \mathcal {O}_{X,x} must be t-conservative. This uniquely determines fx since \mathcal {O}_{X,x} by construction is local, and has a unique prime filter. This then determines fx by looking at the preimage D \to \Gamma \mathcal {O}_{X} \to \mathcal {O}_{X,x}.
